title: Building a Garden of Trust
devotional:
Old Man Hemlock had a peculiar hobby. Every morning, rain or shine, he'd sit on the same park bench, meticulously arranging pebbles. Not just any pebbles, mind you. Each one was hand-picked from the riverbed, cleansed, and then placed in a specific pattern he kept secret from the world. Some folks thought him odd, some pitied him, but most simply ignored the old man and his stones.

One day, a young girl named Lily, known for her insatiable curiosity, approached Hemlock. "What are you doing?" she asked, her eyes wide with wonder.

Hemlock, startled, looked up. His eyes, aged but kind, softened as he gazed at the girl. "I am building a garden," he replied, his voice raspy with age.

Lily frowned. "But it's just pebbles! Where are the flowers? Where are the trees?"

Hemlock smiled. "Ah, but the flowers and trees are in my heart. Each pebble represents a prayer, a hope, a trust placed in the hands of the Gardener who can bring beauty even from the stoniest ground. Some pebbles represent joyous occasions, others are laid down during times of sorrow. Yet each one is carefully placed, trusting that the Gardener knows best." He then explained that sometimes, life feels like a pile of rough, unyielding stones. We struggle to see the beauty, to find the purpose. But faith is arranging those stones, trusting that God, the Master Gardener, will cultivate something beautiful, even miraculous, from our struggles.

Lily sat beside him, silent for a long moment. Then, she picked up a small, grey pebble. "Can I add one?" she asked shyly.

Hemlock nodded, a warm smile spreading across his face. "Indeed you can, child. Indeed, you can. Every stone of trust is welcome here."
image_description: Close-up of smooth river stones arranged in a spiral pattern on a wooden park bench, dappled with sunlight.
insights: Hemlock's pebble garden is a tangible representation of faith in action. Hebrews 11:1 states, 'Now faith is confidence in what we hope for and assurance about what we do not see.' (NIV) Hemlock couldn't see the 'garden' as Lily envisioned it, but he trusted that God would transform his humble offering into something meaningful. This echoes the parable of the mustard seed (Matthew 13:31-32), which illustrates how seemingly insignificant acts of faith can yield extraordinary results.
prayer: Heavenly Father, forgive me for the times I've doubted Your plan, for the moments I've questioned Your hand in my life's story. Help me to see the beauty You create, even from the rough stones of my struggles. Grant me the faith to trust that You are working all things together for good, even when I cannot understand. In Jesus' name, Amen.
reflection: What 'pebbles' are you holding in your life right now? Are you trusting God to use them for good? How can you actively choose to arrange your life's 'stones' with greater faith and hope?
